parts:
Students applying to Junior College from 2028 onwards will use L1R4 score, which requires only 5 O Level subjects instead of 6. With this change, students will need to get 16 points or lower for their L1R4 score, which is made up of one language and four relevant subjects to qualify for JC. This change comes as the Singaporean Ministry of Education (MOE) is taking a further step to broaden learning for students beyond academics.

The change will apply to those in the 2025’s Secondary 2 batch. Students before this batch must achieve an L1R5 score of 20 or lower across six subjects to qualify for JC admission. The L1R5 requirement was introduced in 1989 to specify the subjects counted towards JC admission. This requirement was introduced because of poor passing rates amongst JC students. After that, the passing rate for the A Levels have improved dramatically.

Instead of studying and doing nothing else but study, students will be able to have more time and space to build on their strengths and develop them holistically. Students can take fewer subjects and take some subjects at a less demanding level. Students can then devote more time and effort to pursue their interests and sharpen their soft skills like communication and collaboration in CCAs, school programmes, and classes outside of school. All in all, this is a positive change amongst students as they will be able to develop to be well-rounded people.

Students will now be tested on 5 subjects under the L1R4 system. They will still require English or higher mother tongue along with 3 relevant subjects, including at least one each from Mathematics or Science and Humanities. However, they will now need to include only one additional best-scoring subject instead of two. As we can see, the subject requirements for L1R4 will not have major changes – it is just the total number of subjects that change.

However, the subject requirements to enter JC will remain the same. This is to ensure that students will still have the foundation to enter JC. After all, JC is an important milestone for students who want to go to university and excel at it. Universities in Singapore, particularly the national universities like NUS, SMU and NTU, are demanding and academically rigorous. Students will need a strong foundation to be prepared for the academic rigour of 4 years.

Students who want to go to Millennia Institute (MI) will also need to include 3 subjects following the same combination rules in their L1R4 score, while the qualifying threshold will remain at 20.

The grade requirements for subjects still remain from 2028. To qualify for JC, students need at least a grade 6 for English, grade 7 for Mathematics, and grade 7 for Mother Tongue. If the minimum grades are not obtained, admission may still be granted conditionally.

In 2024, as you may remember, MOE announced a wider admission criteria for polytechnic students from 2028. This new rule allows students to use one subject at the G2 level out of 5 subjects. Currently, students need to offer 5 G3 subjects. This comes after the full subject-based banding system has been implemented in secondary schools, along with a new PSLE scoring system which aims to shift the focus away from emphasising only academic results.

The 2025 Secondary 2 cohort will also be the first to sit for the new Singapore-Cambridge Secondary Education Certificate examinations in 2027, instead of O and N Level examinations. The new SEC will be done under full subject-based banding. By changing these scoring systems and assessment models, students will have an easier time coping with the rigorous demands of the Singaporean education system. MOE wants parents and students to recognise that academic results are important, but they do not solely determine a person’s success.

It mentions changes to policy, and since it's 2025 now, I need to verify claims like “L1R4 will use 16 points or lower, with one language and four relevant subjects.” I'll check official MOE or news sources to confirm.

Also, I need to confirm if MI used L1R4 historically and if the SEC will indeed replace the O/N Level exams by 2027.

The claim about "full subject-based banding" seems to align with past usage of G1/G2/G3. I need to check the part about polytechnic admissions allowing one G2 from five subjects. Also, we should be cautious with JC eligibility, as cutoff points vary. I'll provide corrections, clarity, and factual verification with official MOE sources.

I need to verify the facts from the sources and correct any inaccuracies. Using reliable sources, like MOE press releases for 2024 or 2025, will help. I’ll focus on the most important claims and ensure to cite them properly. I'll search and gather the relevant information to present as corrected facts.

The user’s mention of "grade 6" and "grade 7" is ambiguous. It's better to clarify as "C6 or better in English" and "D7 or better in Math/MTL."

According to the MOE page, all subjects used in L1R4 computation must be at G3. The user's statement about taking fewer subjects or some at a less demanding level is close but requires clarification; subjects taken at G2 won’t count for L1R4. They may opt for fewer O-Level subjects, but not necessarily fewer than before.

The MI threshold remains at 20 with similar subject requirements. We now need to confirm the specific grade requirements for each subject.

parts:
Got it—thanks for pasting the draft. Here’s a tight fact-check + a clean, publication-ready rewrite you can drop in.

# What’s right, what needs fixing (with sources)

- **Core change is correct.** From the **2028 JAE**, JC admission shifts from **L1R5 ≤ 20** to **L1R4 ≤ 16**. MI aligns on subject rules but keeps **L1R4 ≤ 20**. **All five counted subjects must be at G3 level.** Bonus points cap drops to **3** (language elective bonus can sit on top). citeturn1view0  
- **Subject mix (for L1R4) needs precise wording.** It’s **L1 (English or Higher MTL)** + **R1 (one Humanities)** + **R2 (one Mathematics or Science)** + **R3 (one from Hum/Math/Science)** + **R4 (any G3 subject)**. Religious Knowledge can’t be used; you can’t count both HMTL and MTL in the same aggregate. citeturn1view0  
- **Grade minima:** say them explicitly and correctly:  
  – **English (G3): C6 or better**  
  – **Mathematics (G3 Additional Math or Math): D7 or better**  
  – **Mother Tongue:** **D7 or better** if taken at **G3**; **1–5** if at **G2**; **A–D** if at **G1**. **HMTL at G3: E8 or better** also satisfies the MTL requirement. Your “grade 6/7” phrasing is ambiguous—use the exact bands above. citeturn1view0  
- **Conditional admission:** if a candidate misses the specific subject minimum, JC conditional admission is possible with **L1R4 ≤ 12**, or **13–16** **and** **A1–A2 in all four relevant subjects**, with a requirement to re-sit and clear the minimum by end of J1 (else transfer to MI Year 2). MI has a similar but slightly looser threshold. Your draft’s general statement is fine but underspecified. citeturn1view0  
- **Who’s affected first:** the **2025 Sec 2** cohort (who sit **SEC in 2027**) are the first affected by L1R4 in the **2028 JAE**. citeturn2view0turn0search12  
- **Rationale/history:** correct to say L1R5 (1989) addressed poor JC pass rates; A-Level pass rates subsequently improved markedly (≈**65% in 1990** to **~95% in 2023**). citeturn2view0  
- **“Fewer/less demanding subjects” nuance:** MOE encourages students to “recalibrate” load and **may** take one fewer subject overall, but **every subject counted in L1R4 must be at G3**. Avoid implying that lower-level subjects can count toward L1R4—they **can’t**. citeturn1view0turn2view0  
- **Polytechnic admission (context section):** From **AY2028**, students may count **one ‘Best’ [B] subject at G2** in ELR2B2; the other **four must be G3** (if both [B] subjects are G3, the lower-graded one is mapped to G2). Your summary is directionally right; add the “four at G3” detail. citeturn0search20turn0search3

# Polished rewrite (accurate & publication-ready)

**JC & MI admissions: L1R4 from 2028**

From the **2028 Joint Admissions Exercise (JAE)**, junior college (JC) admission will be based on **L1R4 ≤ 16**, instead of the current L1R5 ≤ 20. Millennia Institute (MI) will adopt the same L1R4 subject rules, with an eligibility threshold of **L1R4 ≤ 20**. The bonus-points cap will be **3** (language elective bonuses can be awarded on top of this cap). **All five subjects counted in L1R4 must be offered at G3.** citeturn1view0

**What exactly counts in L1R4?**  
- **L1:** G3 **English** or **Higher Mother Tongue**  
- **R1:** One **Humanities** (best-scoring, G3)  
- **R2:** One **Mathematics or Science** (best-scoring, G3)  
- **R3:** One from **Humanities/Mathematics/Science** (best-scoring, G3)  
- **R4:** Any **G3** subject (best-scoring)  
*Notes:* Religious Knowledge cannot be used. You cannot count both HMTL and MTL in the same aggregate. citeturn1view0

**Minimum subject grades to qualify**  
- **English (G3):** **C6 or better**  
- **Mathematics (G3 Additional Math or Math):** **D7 or better**  
- **Mother Tongue:** **D7 or better (G3)**, **1–5 (G2)**, or **A–D (G1)**. **HMTL (G3): E8 or better** also meets the MTL requirement.  
If a required minimum is missed, **conditional admission** may be possible: **L1R4 ≤ 12**, or **13–16** with **A1–A2 in all four relevant subjects**, subject to re-sitting and clearing the minimum by end of J1 (else transfer to MI Year 2). citeturn1view0

**Who is affected first?**  
The **2025 Secondary 2** cohort will be the first to come under L1R4 when they apply in the **2028 JAE**. This cohort will sit the new **Singapore-Cambridge Secondary Education Certificate (SEC)** examinations in **2027**, which replace the O- and N-Level certificates under Full Subject-Based Banding (G1/G2/G3). citeturn2view0turn0search12

**Why the change?**  
MOE is narrowing the counted subjects from six to five to broaden definitions of success and free up time for students to pursue interests and develop 21st-century competencies—without compromising academic preparedness. Historically, L1R5 was introduced in **1989** to address poor JC pass rates; since then, A-Level pass rates have improved from **~65% (1990)** to **~95% (2023)**. citeturn2view0

**MI alignment**  
MI uses the **same L1R4 subject rules** as JC and an eligibility threshold of **≤ 20**. The specific-subject minima and conditional-admission provisions also apply. citeturn1view0

**Related: Polytechnic admissions from AY2028**  
When computing **ELR2B2**, students may count **one ‘Best’ [B] subject at G2**, while the other **four must be at G3** (with a mapping rule if both [B]s are at G3). This aligns admissions with Full SBB. citeturn0search20turn0search3

---

## Editorial notes on your original text (concise)

- Replace “**tested on 5 subjects**” with “**five subjects are counted for admission**”—they may still *sit* more subjects; the counted five must be **G3**. citeturn1view0  
- Fix MI line: it’s **not “include 3 subjects”**—it’s the same **1 + 4** structure as JC, with **L1R4 ≤ 20**. citeturn1view0  
- State grade minima precisely (C6/D7 bands, and HMTL E8 option). citeturn1view0  
- Keep your “broaden learning” rationale, but anchor it to MOE’s wording and the bonus-points change. citeturn2view0

If you want, I can also tailor a shorter version for social/OG previews and a FAQ box (“Can I count a G2 subject in L1R4?” “What if I fail MTL?” etc.).
